channel.title: BBC Sport
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see https://www.bbc.co.uk/usingthebbc/terms-of-use/#15metadataandrssfeeds for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: O'Reilly scores twice as Man City beat Newcastle
item.description: Manchester City move to within two points of Premier League leaders Arsenal with a tense victory against Newcastle United at Etihad Stadium.

item.title: Ten-man Chelsea drop points again as Burnley score stoppage-time equaliser
item.description: Chelsea make it 17 points dropped from winning positions in the Premier League this season as Zian Flemming's 93rd-minute header gives Burnley a 1-1 draw, after Wesley Fofana is sent off at Stamford Bridge.

item.title: Late Abraham goal rescues point for Villa against Leeds
item.description: Tammy Abraham comes off the bench to score an 88th minute equaliser to cancel out Anton Stach's spectacular freekick, as Aston Villa rescue a 1-1 draw against Leeds United at Villa Park in the Premier League.

item.title: Brighton ease pressure on Hurzeler with win at Brentford
item.description: Goals from Diego Gomez and Danny Welbeck help Brighton to their first league win in six games, as Fabian Hurzeler's side see off Brentford 2-0 at the GTech Community Stadium.

item.title: West Ham held to goalless draw by Bournemouth
item.description: Third-bottom West Ham spurn the chance to put pressure on the teams above them in the table as they are held to a 0-0 draw at home to Bournemouth.

item.title: 'Educate yourself and your kids' - Fofana and Mejbri racially abused
item.description: Burnley midfielder Hannibal Mejbri and Chelsea defender Wesley Fofana have spoken out on social media after being sent racist abuse in the aftermath of the clubs' Premier League match on Saturday.

item.title: Guardiola tells team to chill with cocktails as Man City pile pressure on Arsenal
item.description: As Manchester City continue to crank up the pressure on Arsenal, Pep Guardiola tells his players to take three days off to "enjoy life" with "caipirinhas and daiquiris".

item.title: Red cards and poor home form - Chelsea 'set fire to points'
item.description: Chelsea have more red cards than any side in the Premier League this season, and boss Liam Rosenior says they have "set fire" to points.

item.title: 'Drive and hunger' take Milner to Premier League appearance record
item.description: Brighton's James Milner starts against Brentford to break the all-time Premier League appearance record in his 654th match.

item.title: Deal with 'noise' or join another club - Arteta
item.description: Arsenal boss Mikel Arteta says his players should "be part of a different club" if they can not deal with the "noise" as his team bid to end their 22-year wait for a league title.

item.title: Narrow wins can be 'bedrock of success', Hearts boss says
item.description: Heart of Midlothian head coach Derek McInnes suggests history shows narrow wins can be the difference between success and failure as his Scottish Premiership leaders beat Falkirk.

item.title: 'Like a dream' - Abraham relishing Villa return
item.description: Seven years since firing them into the Premier League, Tammy Abraham is back scoring goals at Aston Villa to keep their fans and players dreaming of glory.

item.title: Tottenham & Newcastle eye Nunez - Sunday's gossip
item.description: Tottenham and Newcastle want to bring Darwin Nunez back to the Premier League, Joe Gomez might leave Liverpool this summer, Roma and Juventus join the race for Marcos Senesi, plus more.

item.title: Chelsea's set-piece defending 'too easy' to play against - Richards
item.description: Match of the Day pundit Micah Richards criticises Chelsea's inability to show "leadership and organisation" in defence, highlighting how Burnley were able to easily attack the home side from set-pieces in their 1-1 draw at Stamford Bridge in the Premier League.

item.title: Chelsea lacked ruthlessness in Burnley draw - Rosenior
item.description: Chelsea head coach Liam Rosenior believes his side lacked the ruthlessness in their 1-1 draw with Burnley at Stamford Bridge in the Premier League.

item.title: Why versatility makes Man City's O'Reilly 'remarkable' - Richards
item.description: BBC Sport pundit Micah Richards explains why Nico O'Reilly should be one of the first names on the Manchester City team sheet, due to the left back's ability to also play in the number 10 role at an "excellent" level.

item.title: This is level we have to play at for rest of season - Guardiola
item.description: Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola is full of praise for forward Erling Haaland and says his side need to play "at this level" for the rest of the season after they beat Newcastle 2-1 at Etihad Stadium.

item.title: Watkins has to respond to pressure of Abraham's arrival at Villa - Rooney
item.description: Match of the Day pundit Wayne Rooney believes Tammy Abraham's arrival at Aston Villa could be key to Ollie Watkins rediscovering his form, as the pressure of competition for his place in the starting line-up is something "he has to respond to."

item.title: From £70 a week to Premier League record 24 years later
item.description: James Milner has broken the Premier League appearance record, 24 years after making his debut as a 16-year-old.

item.title: What's eating Arsenal? North London derby now a test of Gunners' 'bottle'
item.description: What's eating Arsenal? Sunday's North London derby is now a test of the Gunners' "bottle", says chief football writer Phil McNulty.

item.title: 'I still feel I can contribute' - Milner on breaking Premier League record
item.description: James Milner reacts to breaking the record for most appearances in the Premier League.

item.title: Farke 'proud' of his warriors despite disappointment with Villa draw
item.description: Leeds United manager Daniel Farke is "disappointed" with his side's late draw against Aston Villa but believes the result is a "fair outcome" in an "equal game".

item.title: Emery reflects on 'deserved draw' against Leeds
item.description: Aston Villa manager Unai Emery remains upbeat after their draw with Leeds United, saying the result is a point gained rather than two points lost.

item.title: Parker 'proud' of Burnley's 'resilience'
item.description: Burnley head coach Scott Parker says he is "proud" of his side's "resilience" in their 1-1 Premier League draw with Chelsea at Stamford Bridge.

item.title: We're so close, we have to keep pushing - Abraham
item.description: Aston Villa striker Tammy Abraham tells Final Score "anything can happen" in the Premier League title race and that his side have to keep pushing to get close to Arsenal.

item.title: Relegated in February? Why Sheff Wed are on brink of history
item.description: Sheffield Wednesday are on the brink of becoming the first team in English Football League history to be relegated in February.

item.title: 'Losing the dressing room' - what does it mean and how can it happen?
item.description: "Losing the dressing room" is now part of football's vocabulary. Chief football writer Phil McNulty asks what it means, how it happens and can it be solved?

item.title: Tudor could stay at Tottenham for 'long time'
item.description: Sporting director Johan Lange says Igor Tudor could be given the Tottenham job on a permanent basis if he impresses during the remainder of the season.

item.title: Wrexham on march and West Brom's 'precarious position' - Sam Parkin's EFL takeaways
item.description: BBC Final Score pundit Sam Parkin delivers his verdict on the big talking points across the Championship, League One and League Two.

item.title: Kane strikes twice to extend Bayern’s Bundesliga lead
item.description: Harry Kane scores twice as Bayern Munich move nine points clear at the top of the Bundesliga table with victory over Eintracht Frankfurt at the Allianz Arena.

item.title: Watch: Comedy miss as leaders St Johnstone held by Raith Rovers
item.description: Watch as Sam Stanton's shot is cleared off the line by St Johnstone team-mate Josh Fowler during their Scottish Championship game against Raith Rovers.

item.title: Deflected Vieira free-kick earns Hamburg draw against Mainz
item.description: Fabio Vieira's deflected 64th-minute free kick was enough to cancel out Nadiem Amiri's first-half strike to earn Hamburg a point away at Mainz in the Bundesliga.

item.title: 'I'm not good enough' - Glasner's honest admission
item.description: Crystal Palace manager Oliver Glasner has cast doubt on his immediate future at Selhurst Park after admitting he's "not good enough" in the role, following the club's 1-1 draw against Zrinjski in the UEFA Europa Conference League play-offs.

item.title: Mourinho 'got it wrong' - McCarthy
item.description: Former Premier League striker Benni McCarthy says his former manager Jose Mourinho should apologise for his "very wrong" comments after the alleged racial abuse of Vinicius Jr during Real Madrid's 1-0 win against Benfica in the first leg of their Champions League play-off tie.

item.title: 'Commitment, honesty & endeavour' fuelling Wrexham
item.description: Phil Parkinson feels Wrexham's "sheer commitment, honesty and endeavour" was pivotal to their dramatic 5-3 win over Ipswich Town in the Championship.

item.title: Arsenal exactly where we want to be - Arteta
item.description: Mikel Arteta says Arsenal are "exactly where they want to be" in every competition as the Gunners get ready to face rivals Tottenham after the disappointing draw at Wolves.

item.title: Sutton's predictions v Embrace bassist Steve Firth
item.description: BBC Sport football expert Chris Sutton takes on Embrace bassist Steve Firth plus the BBC readers and AI with his predictions for this weekend's Premier League fixtures.

item.title: 'Bigger does not mean better' - why more matches is not for good of the game
item.description: In his BBC Sport column, ex-Premier League boss Tony Pulis explains why more matches in a shorter space of time might mean more injuries, and why the expansion of tournaments does not help players or fans.

item.title: 'It's the ultimate role' - Carrick on Man Utd job
item.description: Manchester United interim boss Michael Carrick joins Mark Chapman to discuss the club's academy, midfielder Kobbie Mainoo and whether he sees himself managing United beyond this season.

item.title: 'Shouldn't be in the game' - Rosenior wants stronger racism penalties
item.description: Chelsea head coach Liam Rosenior believes anyone found guilty of racism should not work in football after Real Madrid's Vinicius Jr allegedly received racist abuse from Benfica's Gianluca Prestianni in the first leg of their Champions League play-off tie in Lisbon.

item.title: Arsenal squander two-goal lead as Wolves score late to earn draw
item.description: A Ricardo Calafiori own goal in the 94th minute gives Wolves a point. as the Premier League's bottom side come back from two goals down against leaders Arsenal at Molineux.

item.title: Balague details aftermath of Vinicius racism allegation
item.description: Champions League Match of the Day pundit Guillem Balague, who attended Real Madrid's match at Benfica, explains the aftermath of the alleged racist incident between Vinicius Jr and Gianluca Prestianni.

item.title: Williams and White react to fans' WSL hot takes
item.description: BBC Sport pundits Fara Williams and Ellen White give their opinion on fans' WSL hot takes from Reddit.

item.title: Arsenal were nowhere near our standards - Arteta
item.description: Mikel Arteta says he is "incredibly disappointed" with his side losing a two goal lead, as Arsenal draw 2-2 against bottom of the table Wolves at Molineux in the Premier League.

item.title: The 20-year-old newspaper column that gave a hint to Man City's new tactics
item.description: Pep Guardiola is using new tactics this season by making Manchester City's attack more narrow, but did he hint at the idea 20 years ago?

item.title: England, Luton & Ted Lasso - Powell's 40 years in football
item.description: Luton Town assistant boss Chris Powell talks to the BBC about his 40 years in football.

item.title: Vinicius: Eight years at Real Madrid, 20 cases of alleged racist abuse
item.description: Spanish football expert Guillem Balague details how Vincius Jr has become a global symbol of resistance against discrimination.

item.title: Is VAR any better in the rest of Europe's top leagues?
item.description: You do not need to look far to find people proclaiming that VAR works fine outside the Premier League. BBC Sport spoke to people across Europe's top leagues to find out.

item.title: 'We really messed up' - does European football need more balance?
item.description: One set of clubs dominate the Champions League, another win their domestic title every year but cannot compete - does European football have a problem?

item.title: How Robert Duvall became an unlikely Scottish football cult hero
item.description: Hollywood actor Robert Duvall, who died on Monday, played Scottish football manager Gordon McLeod in 2000 film A Shot at Glory, which also starred former Ranger Striker Ally McCoist.

item.title: All February's done deals, including deadline day, in one place
item.description: Check out the significant signings and departures in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, EFL and Women's Super League.

item.title: Who has the most Premier League appearances?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything Team look at which players have the highest total Premier League appearances.

item.title: Where do iconic football moves originate from?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain where the names of iconic football moves come from.

item.title: Why is there a four-week break in the WSL?
item.description: BBC Sport takes a look at why there is a second hiatus in the Women's Super League so soon after the winter break.

item.title: Why are some football shin pads so small?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explore why some football shin pads are so small, and what the laws are around wearing them.

item.title: How does the Nations League work and when is the draw?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains how the Uefa Nations League works ahead of the draw for the 2026-27 competition

item.title: What do you get for winning EFL Cup?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains what the winner of the Carabao Cup gets.

item.title: When is transfer deadline day around the world?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain when the transfer deadline is set around the world.

item.title: How badly do 'depressing' Aberdeen need a manager?
item.description: Aberdeen appear content to wait to the summer to appoint a new manager. But after a fifth defeat in six league games, can the club afford to?

item.title: Rangers to open contract talks with Raskin - gossip
item.description: Rangers plan to extend the terms of influential midfielder as Ibrox defender suffers another injury setback.

item.title: Benatia leaves Marseille amid 'growing dissatisfaction'
item.description: Marseille sporting director Medhi Benatia says he is leaving his role just days after the exit of Roberto de Zerbi as manager of the French club.

item.title: Kane reaches 500 goals - what other records could he break?
item.description: Bayern Munich striker Harry Kane became the first Englishman to reach 500 career goals on Saturday, but what other records could he break?

item.title: De Zerbi leaves Marseille by mutual consent
item.description: Roberto de Zerbi, who led Marseille to second in Ligue 1 last season, leaves following their Champions League exit and a 5-0 defeat by Paris St-Germain.

item.title: Real Madrid and Uefa set to end Super League dispute
item.description: Real Madrid and Uefa say they are set to end their legal dispute over the failed European Super League project.

item.title: Lyon loan helping 'explosive' Endrick's World Cup 'dream' with Brazil
item.description: Real Madrid striker Endrick's impact on loan at Lyon has been immediate, and is fuelling the teenager's "dream" of playing for Brazil at the World Cup.

item.title: Lucky break that changed Alexander-Arnold's Real future
item.description: Trent Alexander-Arnold endured a difficult start at Real Madrid but his prospects are looking up - and it might earn him a ticket to the World Cup.

item.title: Second only to England - why so many Swedes are in WSL
item.description: BBC World Service's More Than The Score podcast looks at the growing influence of Swedish talent into the Women's Super League.

item.title: Is the new UWCL format easier for English teams?
item.description: Three English teams have reached the quarter-finals of the Women's Champions League this season - but has it been as easy as it appears?

item.title: Millwall FC apologise over London City fixture
item.description: Millwall apologise to their supporters club, fan advisory board and Millwall Lionesses after the scheduling of a London City Lionesses game at The Den.

item.title: Rafferty returns for NI's World Cup qualifiers
item.description: Experienced Rangers defender Laura Rafferty is part of new interim manager Kris Lindsay's first Northern Ireland squad for the opening 2027 World Cup qualifiers.

item.title: Women's FA Cup revamp on hold after 'ridiculous idea' criticism
item.description: Plans to change the format of the Women's FA Cup, which would have seen four sides seeded and pathways to Wembley mapped out from the last 32 onwards, will not be brought in next season.

item.title: 'Brilliant' Park strikes again for Man Utd
item.description: Jess Park scores a stunner in Manchester United's 2-0 win over Atletico Madrid, sealing their place in the quarter-finals of the Women's Champions League.

item.title: Frank's downfall: Inside his struggle to get players and fans onboard
item.description: Thomas Frank has been sacked as Tottenham manager after just eight months in charge. BBC Sport's Sami Mokbel takes a closer look at his tenure.

item.title: Cages, crushes and stabbings - is European away safety getting worse?
item.description: BBC Sport explores the safety issues fans face when following their team across Europe.

item.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
item.description: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

item.title: Captain, player, manager, Mister, number one - Davids at Barnet
item.description: BBC Sport remembers Edgar Davids' 15 months as Barnet player-manager in League Two and the Conference.

item.title: From farming village to Liverpool icon - the Salah story
item.description: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

item.title: Napoli 'smell blood' & target Premier League's discarded stars
item.description: After Scott McTominay was a hit, Napoli went back to the Premier League for Kevin de Bruyne, could more players follow them to Serie A?

item.title: When River Plate icon Diaz took over fourth-tier Oxford
item.description: Twenty years on from Ramon Diaz's surprising appointment at Oxford United, BBC Sport looks at what happened and how it went.
